abstract.para: You can check the status of &qdevice; and &qnet; from any node in the cluster. These examples show a cluster with two nodes, &node1; and &node2;.

example.title: Showing the status of &qdevice;
example.screen:
&prompt.user;sudo crm corosync status quorum 1 &node1; member 2 &node2; member
Quorum information ------------------ Date: [...] Quorum provider: corosync_votequorum Nodes: 2 Node ID: 2 Ring ID: 1.e Quorate: Yes
Votequorum information ---------------------- Expected votes: 3 Highest expected: 3 Total votes: 3 Quorum: 2 Flags: Quorate Qdevice
Membership information ---------------------- Nodeid Votes Qdevice Name 1 1 A,V,NMW &node1; 2 1 A,V,NMW &node2; (local) 0 1 Qdevice

topic.para: The Membership information section shows the following status codes:

listitem.para: Shows the connectivity status between &qdevice; and &corosync;.
Shows if the node has a vote. V means that both nodes can communicate with each other. In a split-brain scenario, one node would be set to V and the other node would be set to NV.

varlistentry.term: MW (master wins) or NMW (not master wins)

listitem.para: Shows if the master_wins flag is set. By default, the flag is not set, so the status is NMW.
Shows that the cluster is not using a quorum device.

example.title: Showing the status of &qnet;
example.screen:
&prompt.user;sudo crm corosync status qnetd 1 &node1; member 2 &node2; member
